‘Vieux-Port’ in Marseilles, the reader cannot help but think of the death of a young black man, Mamadou Traoré, in similar circumstances in Paris in 1995.
The allegation of racist violence is made even more precise by the fact that the author adds that the crime was committed in the presence of ‘several hundred people’ who were ‘watching the scene with a certain satisfaction’. This detail is intended to show that the crime was committed in a public place, in front of witnesses who approved of it. The allegation is therefore defamatory, and the author should have taken care to ensure that it was not false.
The Court of Appeal held that the allegation was not defamatory because it was not made in a sufficiently precise manner. It considered that the words ‘in the presence of several hundred people’ did not mean that the crime was committed in a public place, but only that the witnesses were present at the scene of the crime.
The Supreme Court has rejected this interpretation. It held that the words ‘in the presence of several hundred people’ do not merely mean that the witnesses were present at the scene of the crime, but that they were present in a public place and that they were watching the crime being committed. It added that the author should have taken care to ensure that the allegation was not false, because it was not a question of a literary fiction but of a real event, and because the allegation was likely to be taken seriously by the reader.
The Supreme Court held that the author had committed a fault, and that the allegation was defamatory. It ordered him to pay €1 in damages to Jean-Marie Le Pen.
Comment
This decision is remarkable for several reasons. Firstly, it is unusual for a politician to sue for defamation in respect of a work of fiction. Secondly, the Supreme Court has confirmed that the allegation was defamatory, even though it was not made in a sufficiently precise manner. It held that the author should have taken care to ensure that the allegation was not false, because it was not a question of a literary fiction but of a real event, and because the allegation was likely to be taken seriously by the reader. This is a reminder that the author of a work of fiction is not exempt from the rules of defamation law, and that he or she must take care to ensure that the allegations made in the work are not defamatory.

“Azerbaijan” and “Ardahan” were created in 1878 and 1879 respectively. In 1905 the Ottoman Empire was defeated in the Russo-Turkish War and the Caucasus was divided between Russia and Iran. In 1918 the Ottoman Empire was defeated in World War I and the Caucasus was divided between Russia and the newly formed Turkish Republic.

The 1920 Treaty of Alexandropol between the Soviet Union and the Turkish Republic recognized the Soviet Union's control over the Caucasus. In 1921 the Soviet Union established the Transcaucasian SFSR, which was later dissolved in 1936. In 1937 the Soviet Union established the Azerbaijani SSR, which was later dissolved in 1991.

The Soviet Union annexed the territory of the former Ottoman Empire in the Caucasus in 1921, and in 1924 it was divided into several administrative units, including the Nagorno-Karabakh Autonomous Oblast. In 1936 the Soviet Union dissolved the Transcaucasian SFSR and created the Georgian SSR, the Armenian SSR, and the Azerbaijani SSR. In 1945 the Soviet Union annexed the territory of the former Iranian Azerbaijan and created the Nagorno-Karabakh Autonomous Oblast within the Azerbaijani SSR.

In 1991 the Soviet Union dissolved and the Azerbaijani SSR became the independent Republic of Azerbaijan. In 1991 the Nagorno-Karabakh Autonomous Oblast declared independence from Azerbaijan and became the Nagorno-Karabakh Republic, which is not recognized by any country in the world.

The conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan over Nagorno-Karabakh escalated in the 1990s and led to a war in 1991-1994. In 1994 the ceasefire was signed and a peace process was initiated. However, the conflict remains unresolved and the situation in the region is tense.

The Court also found that the respondent State had failed to comply with the requirements of Article 5 § 4 of the Convention.
The Court found that the respondent State had not provided any explanation of the reasons why the French investigating judge had not been present during the interrogation of S.A. by the Syrian authorities.
In addition, the Court noted that the respondent State had not provided any explanation of the reasons why the French investigating judge had not been present during the interrogation of M.B. by the Syrian authorities.
The Court therefore found that the respondent State had not complied with the requirements of Article 5 § 4 of the Convention.
The Court awarded the applicants 30,000 euros (EUR) in respect of non-pecuniary damage.

Article 54 § 1 of the Constitution of the Republic of Poland of 2 April 1997 provides:

“Everyone has the right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion. This right includes the freedom to profess any religion or belief, either individually or collectively, in public or in private, through teaching, practice, worship or observance. No one may be forced to profess a religion or belief, to perform religious rites or to take part in them. No one may be discriminated against because of his or her religion or belief. The exercise of this right may be restricted only by the provisions of the law and only in order to protect the rights and freedoms of others, to protect public order, health and morality, or to protect the rights and freedoms of the State.”

I also remember the words of one of the refugees from Khojaly, who told me that the Armenians had been firing on the town from the surrounding hills for several days before the attack, but the people of Khojaly did not want to leave their homes, as they believed that the Russian troops would come to their rescue. And only when the Armenians broke through the defense line and entered the town, the people of Khojaly realized that they had been betrayed by the Russians.
In the end, the people of Khojaly had to leave their homes in a hurry and in panic, and many of them were killed during the flight. I remember that the refugee from Khojaly told me that he saw how the Armenians were shooting at the fleeing people from the roofs of the houses. He also told me that he had been hiding in the basement of one of the houses and had witnessed how the Armenians had been killing the people who had been hiding there. He said that the Armenians had been shooting at the people through the windows and the doors of the house, and that the screams of the dying people had been heard from the basement.
The refugee from Khojaly also told me that he had seen how the Armenians had been killing the people who had been hiding in the houses. He said that the Armenians had been shooting at the people through the windows and the doors of the house, and that the screams of the dying people had been heard from the basement.
It is hard to imagine that people could do such things to their neighbors, to their fellow human beings. But the fact remains that the Armenians did not spare anyone in Khojaly. They killed the elderly, the women, the children, and the men. And they did it in a particularly cruel and barbaric way.
The Khojaly tragedy was a great tragedy for all the Azerbaijani people. It was a tragedy for the Azerbaijani state. And it was a tragedy for the entire civilized world. But the tragedy of Khojaly was not the only tragedy that befell the Azerbaijani people. The Armenians have been committing similar atrocities against the Azerbaijani people for many years. On 24 August 2011 the applicant was removed from Russia to Kyrgyzstan.
COMPLAINTS
The applicant complains under Article 3 of the Convention that he was subjected to inhuman and degrading treatment in detention. He also complains under Article 5 § 1 of the Convention that his detention was unlawful.
THE LAW
The applicant complains under Article 3 of the Convention that he was subjected to inhuman and degrading treatment in detention. He also complains under Article 5 § 1 of the Convention that his detention was unlawful. The Court considers that these complaints are not manifestly ill-founded within the meaning of Article 35 § 3 of the Convention. No other grounds for declaring them inadmissible have been established.
RULING
FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT UNANIMOUSLY
1. Declares the complaints under Article 3 and Article 5 § 1 of the Convention admissible and the remainder of the application inadmissible;
2. Holds that there has been a violation of Article 3 of the Convention in respect of the applicant;
3. Holds that there has been no violation of Article 5 § 1 of the Convention.
Done in English, and notified in writing on 23 May 2012, pursuant to Rule 77 §§ 2 and 3 of the Rules of Court.

The applicant was born in the city of Tomsk, in the Russian Federation. He is of Russian nationality. He has a secondary education and has worked as a driver and a builder. He is married and has a daughter born in 1997.

The applicant was convicted of the following offences:

1. In 2001, the applicant was convicted of armed robbery of Ms L. in the city of Tomsk. He was sentenced to seven years' imprisonment.

2. In 2003, the applicant was convicted of the murder of Ms L. and attempted murder of a policeman during his arrest. He was sentenced to twenty-five years' imprisonment.

The applicant appealed against his conviction. In 2004, the Tomsk Regional Court amended the applicant's conviction and reduced the sentence to twenty-five years' imprisonment.

In 2006, the applicant's appeal against his conviction was rejected by the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation.

The applicant is serving his sentence in penal colony FBU IK-5, where he is detained in a single cell. He has no contact with other prisoners. He spends most of his time reading books and writing letters. He is allowed to receive parcels containing food, clothes and personal hygiene items. “The enjoyment of the rights and freedoms set forth in this Convention shall be secured without discrimination on any ground such as sex, race, colour, language, religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, association with a national minority, property, birth or other status.”
34.  The Government contested that argument.
35.  The Court considers that this complaint is manifestly ill-founded and must be rejected in accordance with Article 35 §§ 3 and 4 of the Convention.
IV. OTHER ALLEGED VIOLATIONS OF THE CONVENTION
36.  The applicants also complained that the refusal of the authorities to register the “Moldovan Party” violated Articles 10, 11 and 13 of the Convention.

The Court noted that the Ojas Meditation Centre had not been able to show that it had a religious character. It did not have a creed, a set of beliefs or a moral code that could be seen as a religious teaching. Its main aim was not to connect with a supreme being, but to help individuals to find their own spiritual path.
The Court noted that the Osho movement did not have a hierarchical structure, and that the Ojas Meditation Centre was not a member of any organisation or association. The Court also noted that the Ojas Meditation Centre did not have a place of worship, but only a meditation hall. The Court concluded that the Ojas Meditation Centre did not have the characteristics of a religious community.
The Supreme Administrative Court also rejected the Ojas Meditation Centre’s argument that the Ministry of Justice had violated its right to freedom of religion. The Court noted that the right to freedom of religion was not absolute, and that it was subject to limitations in order to protect public order, health and morals. The Court concluded that the Ministry of Justice’s decision did not violate the Ojas Meditation Centre’s right to freedom of religion.
The Supreme Administrative Court’s judgment is final.
This case is significant because it shows that a movement that is not recognised as a religion in most European countries is not automatically considered a religion in Lithuania. The applicants' appeal against the judgment of the Chişinău Court was dismissed on 14 October 2007.
B. Relevant domestic law
The Assemblies Act (Law No. 133-XVI of 7 July 1994) provides for the right to freedom of assembly. Article 11(1) of the Assemblies Act requires that the organisers of a public assembly must submit an application for authorisation to the local authorities at least fifteen days before the planned assembly. The application must indicate the place, date and time of the assembly, its objectives and the expected number of participants. The local authorities have the power to prohibit the assembly or to impose conditions on it. If the local authorities fail to reply to the application within five days, the organisers may hold the assembly without the authorisation of the local authorities.
C. Relevant international law
Article 11 of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) provides that “everyone has the right to freedom of peaceful assembly and to freedom of association with others, including the right to form and to join trade unions for the protection of his interests”.

They had not submitted an application to the local authorities and had failed to inform the local authorities of their intention to hold a protest. The Government further stated that the applicants had not challenged the validity of the administrative fine imposed on them.

1.  The Parties may appeal a decision of the Commission to the Arbitral Tribunal within 30 days of the date of the decision.

The report stated that the Committee had received information that “the United States of America had been using the territory of a number of European countries for the purpose of transporting and detaining individuals suspected of involvement in terrorist activities, without the knowledge of their governments and in violation of their national laws”. 
39.  The Committee concluded that the “extraordinary renditions” were a “serious violation of the sovereignty of the countries concerned and of the principles of democracy, the rule of law and human rights”. 
40.  The Committee also stated that “the use of secret detention centres, the absence of any judicial control and the possibility of the use of torture or inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment in such centres are incompatible with the European Convention on Human Rights and the case-law of the European Court of Human Rights”. 
41.  The Committee recommended that the Council of Europe member States should “take all necessary measures to ensure that their territory is not used for the purpose of ‘extraordinary renditions’ and that their airspace is not used for the transportation of individuals suspected of involvement in terrorist activities”. 
42.  The Committee also recommended that the Council of Europe member States should “take all necessary measures to ensure that the European Convention on Human Rights is respected in all circumstances and that any individual suspected of involvement in terrorist activities is brought before a judge and tried in accordance with the principles of the rule of law”. 
43.  On 17 January 2006 the Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe adopted Resolution (2006)1 on “the alleged secret detention centres in Council of Europe member States”. 
44.  The Committee of Ministers expressed its concern “at the allegations of the existence of secret detention centres in Council of Europe member States, which may have been used to detain persons suspected of involvement in terrorist activities”.

Girls are circumcised traditionally to prepare them for marriage, for religious reasons and – based on superstition – for ‘health reasons’. On 15 November 2000 the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation refused to review the applicant’s appeal against the military court’s judgment.

137. The applicant complained that the domestic authorities had failed to investigate the abduction of his brother and to punish the perpetrators. He relied on Articles 2, 3, 5, 13 and 14 of the Convention.

138. The Government submitted that the applicant’s complaint was inadmissible. They argued that the applicant had failed to exhaust domestic remedies, as he had not pursued the criminal proceedings against his brother’s abductors. They also submitted that the applicant had failed to demonstrate that the authorities had been involved in the abduction.

139. The Court notes that the applicant complained that the authorities had failed to investigate the abduction of his brother and to punish the perpetrators. The Court considers that the applicant has exhausted domestic remedies in respect of this complaint. It is true that the applicant did not pursue the criminal proceedings against his brother’s abductors, but the Court considers that this was because the authorities had refused to open a criminal investigation into the abduction. The Court considers that the applicant’s failure to pursue the criminal proceedings did not prevent him from exhausting domestic remedies in respect of his complaint that the authorities had failed to investigate the abduction.

140. The Court further notes that the Government did not submit any evidence to show that the authorities had not been involved in the abduction. On the contrary, the Government submitted that the applicant’s brother had been abducted by law-enforcement officers.

141. The Court therefore concludes that there has been a violation of Article 2 of the Convention in respect of the applicant’s complaint that the authorities had failed to investigate the abduction of his brother and to punish the perpetrators.

III. ALLEGED VIOLATION OF ARTICLE 5 OF THE CONVENTION
142. The applicant complained that his brother had been abducted by law-enforcement officers and that he had been deprived of his liberty for a period of 10 days from 18 to 28 August 2000. He relied on Article 5 of the Convention.

[Nigeria] have laws prohibiting FGM/C, but the penalties are not sufficiently stringent. FGM/C is practiced in many parts of the country, particularly in the north, and is often performed on girls before the age of 15. The practice is more prevalent in rural areas and among some ethnic groups. The law provides penalties of up to five years’ imprisonment and a fine of up to 50,000 naira ($300) for anyone who performs FGM/C. However, enforcement of the law was weak, and FGM/C continued to be performed in many parts of the country. According to the 2013 Demographic and Health Survey, 27 percent of women and girls between the ages of 15 and 49 had undergone FGM/C. According to the UN Population Fund, 32 percent of women and girls in the country have undergone FGM/C. According to the National Agency for the Prohibition of Trafficking in Persons (NAPTIP), there were 5,892 reported cases of FGM/C in 2014, compared with 5,444 cases in 2013.

33.  The Committee is concerned that the prevalence of FGM/C remains high in the State party, despite the existence of legislation prohibiting the practice. It is also concerned that the penalties provided for in the legislation are not sufficiently stringent to deter the practice.

34. The Committee recommends that the State party strengthen its efforts to combat FGM/C, including by increasing awareness-raising campaigns and training of law enforcement officials, medical professionals and traditional leaders, and by implementing more stringent penalties for those who perform FGM/C. The Committee recommends that the State party ensure that FGM/C is criminalized at the federal level and that all states have laws prohibiting the practice. The Committee recommends that the State party allocate sufficient resources to the National Agency for the Prohibition of Trafficking in Persons to ensure that it is able to effectively combat FGM/C. The Committee recommends that the State party provide comprehensive and age-appropriate education and awareness-raising programmes to girls and boys, as well as to their parents and guardians, on the harmful effects of FGM/C and the rights of girls and women to bodily integrity. THE LAW
1. The applicants complained under Article 2 of the Convention that Suliman Yunusov had been abducted by servicemen of the Russian federal forces in Grozny on 25 February 2005 and that the authorities had failed to carry out an effective investigation into his disappearance. They relied on Article 2 of the Convention, which provides:

“1. The right to life shall be protected by law. No one shall be deprived of his life intentionally save in the execution of a sentence of a court following his conviction of a crime for which this penalty is provided by law.

2. The intentional killing of one human being by another is unlawful unless it amounts to lawful killing or is excusable on the grounds of self-defence.”

The applicants also relied on Article 3 of the Convention, which provides:

“No one shall be subjected to torture or to inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.”

2. The Court notes that the Government did not provide any information about the investigation into the disappearance of Suliman Yunusov. It notes that the applicants’ complaints under Article 2 of the Convention are not manifestly ill-founded within the meaning of Article 35 § 3 of the Convention. No other grounds for declaring them inadmissible have been established

II. RELEVANT DOMESTIC LAW AND PRACTICE
A. The Russian Code of Administrative Offences
Article 19.3 of the Russian Code of Administrative Offences provides:
“Unauthorised entry into or presence in the restricted areas of ... [specified] institutions or facilities ... shall be punished by a fine of up to 500 roubles, or by administrative arrest for up to fifteen days, or by compulsory labour for up to forty hours.”
B. The Law on Advocates
Article 15 of the Law on Advocates provides:
“Advocates shall have the right to access their clients and to hold private conversations with them, to examine documents and other materials relevant to the case, and to have copies made of them.
Advocates shall have the right to be present at their clients’ interrogations, examinations, and other investigative actions, and to be informed of the results of those actions.”

53. The applicant then applied to the European Court of Human Rights, claiming that the domestic courts had failed to give a proper assessment of the facts and the evidence and had failed to establish the identity of the perpetrators of the alleged crime.
54. The Government contested the admissibility of the application. They submitted that the applicant had not exhausted domestic remedies, as he had not applied to the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation to quash the investigator’s decision of 12 November 2004.
55. The applicant submitted that he had exhausted domestic remedies. He argued that the Supreme Court had not been able to give a proper assessment of the facts and the evidence and had not established the identity of the perpetrators of the alleged crime. He also argued that the Supreme Court had not given any reasons for its decision.
56. The Court notes that the applicant did not challenge the investigator’s decision of 12 November 2004 before the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation. He only challenged the decision of the Kurgan Regional Court of Appeal of 11 April 2005. The Court considers that the applicant did not exhaust domestic remedies in respect of the investigator’s decision of 12 November 2004.
57. The Court therefore considers that the application is inadmissible under Article 35 § 1 of the Convention.
FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT UNANIMOUSLY
1. Declares the application inadmissible.

The “MRT” then began to purchase gas from Ukraine, which was cheaper than the gas supplied by Gazprom.
In 2016, Gazprom resumed gas supplies to the region, but only after the “MRT” agreed to pay USD 1 billion for the gas consumed in 2015.
The gas issue in Transdniestria is a complex one, and it is difficult to determine who is to blame for the current situation. However, it is clear that the “MRT” is not able to pay for gas supplies, and the Russian Government is unwilling to take on this responsibility. The only solution seems to be to continue to purchase gas from Ukraine, which is cheaper than the gas supplied by Gazprom.

There has accordingly been a violation of Article 2 of the Convention in the present case.

The applicant complained that her brother-in-law and his family had been subjected to inhuman treatment by Russian servicemen and that their abduction had been in violation of Article 3 of the Convention.

Article 3 of the Convention provides:

“No one shall be subjected to torture or to inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.”

The Court notes that the applicant did not provide any specific information or evidence concerning the treatment of her brother-in-law and his family. The Court therefore finds that the applicant has not substantiated her claim under Article 3 of the Convention.

It follows that this complaint is manifestly ill-founded and must be rejected in accordance with Article 35 §§ 3 and 4 of the Convention.

126.  In the light of the above, the Court considers that the applicant has suffered non-pecuniary damage as a result of the violation of Article 5 § 1 of the Convention. Making its assessment on an equitable basis, the Court awards the applicant EUR 1,000 in respect of non-pecuniary damage.

B. Costs and expenses
127.  The applicant claimed EUR 2,000 in respect of the costs and expenses incurred before the Court.

128.  The Government did not comment on this claim.

129.  In accordance with the Court’s case-law, costs and expenses follow the event and are recoverable in so far as they have been actually and necessarily incurred and are reasonable as to quantum. In the present case, the Court does not find it necessary to award the applicant any costs and expenses under this head.

C. Default interest

The applicants’ claims were rejected by the domestic courts. In particular, the Supreme Court of the Primorskiy Region held that the applicants had failed to prove that the authorities had acted negligently in the circumstances of the case. It also rejected the applicants’ argument that the authorities had been under a duty to warn them of the danger of flooding.

The applicants then lodged a complaint with the Constitutional Court, claiming that the domestic courts had violated their right to a fair hearing and their right to compensation for the loss of their property. They relied on Article 6 § 1 of the Convention, which provides:

“In the determination of his civil rights and obligations or of any criminal charge against him, everyone is entitled to a fair and public hearing within a reasonable time by an independent and impartial tribunal established by law.”

They also relied on Article 1 of Protocol No. 1, which provides:

“Every natural or legal person is entitled to the peaceful enjoyment of his possessions. No one shall be deprived of his possessions except in the public interest and subject to the conditions provided for by law and by the general principles of international law.”

The Constitutional Court dismissed the applicants’ complaint. It held that the domestic courts had not violated the applicants’ right to a fair hearing, and that the applicants had not provided any evidence to support their claim that the authorities had acted negligently. It also held that the applicants had not been deprived of their possessions except in the public interest, and that the authorities had acted in accordance with the general principles of international law.

The applicants then brought an application to the European Court of Human Rights, complaining that the domestic courts had violated their rights under Articles 6 and 1 of Protocol No. 1.

The Court notes that the applicants’ complaint concerns the State’s duty to provide adequate compensation for damage caused by natural disasters. It reiterates that the State’s duty to protect property is not absolute and that it may be subject to limitations in the interests of the general public. The Court recalls that the State’s duty to protect property is particularly important in cases where the State has created a danger or hazard that is likely to cause damage to property. In such cases, the State must take reasonable measures to protect the property of those who are likely to be affected by the danger or hazard.

B. Relevant domestic law and practice
1. Criminal Code
Article 30 of the Criminal Code provides that a person who uses force or threats of force against a person who is in custody, detention or imprisonment, or against a person who is being taken to a place of detention or imprisonment, shall be punished by imprisonment for a term of up to three years.
Article 293 provides that a person who inflicts or orders to inflict cruel treatment or torture on a person who is in custody, detention or imprisonment, shall be punished by imprisonment for a term of up to ten years.
2. Code of Criminal Procedure
Article 97 of the Code of Criminal Procedure provides that a person who has been subjected to torture or other cruel treatment may apply to the prosecutor’s office to institute criminal proceedings against the person who committed the offence.
Article 98 provides that the prosecutor’s office shall examine the application within three days and, if it finds that there are grounds for instituting criminal proceedings, shall institute them.
Article 99 provides that the prosecutor’s office shall not institute criminal proceedings if it finds that the application is groundless.
Article 100 provides that the prosecutor’s office shall inform the applicant of its decision.
Article 101 provides that the prosecutor’s office shall inform the applicant of the reasons for its decision.
Article 102 provides that the applicant may appeal against the prosecutor’s office’s decision to a court within ten days.

25. The relevant domestic law and practice concerning the protection of personal data and the confidentiality of journalistic sources is set out in the following paragraphs.

26. The Romanian Constitution of 1991 (the Constitution) provides for the protection of privacy and the secrecy of correspondence and other means of communication. Article 26 § 1 of the Constitution states that “the secrecy of correspondence, of postal, telegraphic and telephonic communications is inviolable. The secrecy of other means of communication is protected by law.” Article 26 § 2 of the Constitution states that “the secrecy of correspondence, of postal, telegraphic and telephonic communications and of other means of communication may be limited only by law and only in the cases and under the conditions provided for by the law.”

27. The Romanian Criminal Code (the Code) provides for criminal offences in relation to the protection of personal data and the confidentiality of journalistic sources. Article 226 of the Code provides that the unlawful disclosure of personal data shall be punished by imprisonment of between six months and two years. Article 226 § 1 of the Code provides that the unlawful disclosure of personal data shall be punished by imprisonment of between one and five years if the offence is committed by a public official or by a person who has been entrusted with the processing of personal data. Article 226 § 2 of the Code provides that the unlawful disclosure of personal data shall be punished by imprisonment of between two and seven years if the offence is committed in order to obtain a pecuniary advantage.

28. The Code also provides for criminal offences in relation to the confidentiality of journalistic sources. Article 226 § 3 of the Code provides that the unlawful disclosure of the identity of a person who has provided information to a journalist in the exercise of his or her profession shall be punished by imprisonment of between one and five years.
